column3: Aristotle had described the elements of an ideal tragety as a complex plan, imitating actions which exite pity and fear, and satisfy the moral sense.  As he said in the second paragraph, " A perfect tragedy should, as we have seen, be arranged not on the simple but on the complex plan. It should, moreover, imitate actions which excite pity and fear, this being the distinctive mark of tragic imitation." This is what he thinks tragety is suppoused to be like and how he understands it, its also how he wants us to understand it and focus on the main points.
column4: Aristotle perceived the essence of tragedy through a complex lens, mirroring the actions that evoke a sense of pity and fear, fulfilling the moral sense. He argued that a tragic composition should exhibit this distinct feature, a characteristic that distinguishes tragedy from other forms of entertainment.

column3: In the ancient Egyptian system of government, anybody could move up in the system. "Right below the pharaoh in status were powerful nobles and priests".  For example, they worked hard to get right below the pharaoh and the way they did that was to donate to the gods.  "All Egyptians—from pharaohs to farmers—gave gifts to the gods." By doing that helped they move up in the system. "It was possible for a boy born on a farm to work his way up into the higher ranks of the government." This proves even if you are poor or have a low rank if you work hard and please the gods then you could have a higher rank in the government.
column4: In ancient Egyptian governance, anyone could climb the social ladder by working hard and pleasing the gods. Nobles and priests held positions close to the pharaoh due to generous contributions to the gods. Every citizen, from pharaohs to farmers, bestowed offerings to the gods, seeking favor for their advancement in the government. This principle allowed anyone, regardless of class or standing, to rise to prominence through hard work and devotion to the gods. The socioeconomic barriers that may have restricted other societies were seemingly nonexistent for those who adhered to these principles.

column3: One element is that the subject should not be a particularly good or bad man, but just a man like each of us.  Another element is that the fortune should go from good to bad because of a mistake. If fortune changes because of fate, that's fate's fault, but by a mistake or flaw so that it is relatable. Thirdly, the plot should be simple. Decent person loses everything by their own mistake. The end. "In the second rank comes the kind of tragedy which... has a double thread of plot, and also an opposite catastrophe for the good and for the bad." Aristotle also mentions how the "bad guy" shouldn't be punished on-play as "a plot of this kind would, doubtless, satisfy the moral sense, but it would inspire neither pity nor fear..." To arouse pity and fear is the goal of a tragedy for Aristotle.

column3: Different social classes were involved in the government by having the lower classes do harder work, and the higher classes with more people usually had hard, but more important work. In the text, it says, "All laws were enacted at the discretion of the pharaoh. Each frmer paid taxes in the form of grains, which were stored in the pharaoh's warehouses." It also says in the text, "Right below the pharaoh in status were powerful nobles and priests. Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh." Lastly, it says in the text, "Soldiers fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings. During long periods of peace, soldiers also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved in building such structures as pyramids and palaces." This evidence supports that different social classes were involved in the government by having lower classes do harder work, and the people with the higher classes usually had hard, but more important work.
column4: Social classes were intertwined, with lower classes contributing essential labor while the higher classes held more demanding roles. The government's decisions were shaped by the complex interplay of these social classes, with nobles and priests wielding significant influence due to their power and access to significant resources. Soldiers acted as guardians of the populace, controlling various segments of society and ensuring their well-being, with the lower classes fulfilling the majority of construction tasks.

column3: The structure of the ancient Egyptian system of government was structured like a pyramid. The pharohs were at the top of the social class, believed to have been god like, or gods in human form. They had "absolute power over their subjects," (Paragraph 2.), percieved to have no limitation to what they could possibly do. Under the pharohs, were the pharohs second in command, known as viziers. They were the people that had to record if taxes were collected. They are supposed to help the pharohs with his duties. Finally, the last social class within the government are the nobles. They are the only class that can hold government positions. They gained money through the tributes, or gifts paid to the pharaoh. Since we know the pharoh was basically a god, they were either paying to him or the other core gods of their society, which included Ra, Osiris and Isis. Every egyptian, including "pharaohs to farmers—gave gifts to the gods," (Paragraph 7.) Moving on, different social classes were involved in the government due to taxation and bueraucracy. For instance, although the pharohs and state leaders held control over what the laws were,  people could still choose whether they wanted these laws or not. Additionally, an example of a different social class being involved in the government were farmers. Farmers were taxed up to 60% of their crop to the pharohs annually, (Paragraph 12.) This allowed the pharohs and nobles to distribute foods from warehouses if need be, such as in a famine or food shortage. Therefore, this is how the social structure of Egypt was built, as well as how other social classes helped within the government.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  The ancient Egyptian system of government was structured like a pyramid. At the top of the pyramid were the pharohs, who were believed to be gods in human form. Below them were the viziers, who were responsible for recording taxes. The nobles were the last social class in the government and were appointed by the pharaoh. Everyone, from farmers to pharaohs, gave gifts to the gods in exchange for protection and prosperity. This pyramid-shaped government system was designed to ensure that the pharaoh had the resources he needed to maintain order and maintain his own power.

column3: The factory would often use methods such as chemicals to atempt to neutralize the smell of the spoiled meat, or a stronger pickle to put in the hams to destroy the odor. Some people would extract the bone from where the bad smell was located and it usually killed of the scent, " And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor—a process known to the workers as “giving them thirty per cent.” Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as “Number Three Grade,” but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade—there was only Number One Grade. The packers were always originating such schemes—they had what they called “boneless hams,” which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; "(The Jungle).
column4: Reworded Passage:  Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  The factory employed methods, including chemical treatments and stronger pickles, to neutralize the smell of spoiled meat. Extraction of the bone from the affected area, followed by insertion of a white-hot iron, was another technique used to eliminate the odor. While this was successful in reducing the smell, it sometimes resulted in the release of spoiled hams that were difficult to handle. Over time, the factory adopted a new method that involved extracting the bone from the affected area and inserting a hot iron into it, which eliminated the odor completely. This procedure, known as "number thirty per cent," became the standard, resulting in a lack of distinction between the various grades of hams.

column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  The Egyptian government, much like a tiered system, consists of classes with distinct ranks. The top tier is occupied by the Pharaohs, who hold ultimate power and control through their authority. This is well-established in Paragraph 2.  Additionally, some individuals were elevated to a higher status, becoming the "Nobles." They possessed the ability to influence the government, holding positions of influence due to their positions of power.  The priestly class, directly below the pharaoh, played a vital role in influencing and mediating divine favor. They held positions of immense influence and were accountable to the pharaoh for ensuring favorable outcomes in their endeavors.  The soldiers, situated at the bottom of the hierarchy, exemplified the unwavering commitment and service of the citizenry. They participated in both wars and domestic upheavals, ensuring the safety and stability of the nation.  Lastly, at the base of the social structure were the slaves and farmers, whose plight was marked by captivity and subjugation. Slavery became the fate for those captured in times of war or upheaval, serving as forced laborers in the construction of structures such as pyramids and palaces.

column4: The Egyptian social structure was characterized by a hierarchical pyramid, with the pharaoh at the apex. The nobles held the highest position and provided the ruling elite with substantial financial resources through tributes. The priesthood held a significant role, responsible for mediating between the pharaoh and the gods through rituals and sacrifices. Soldiers, artisans, and shopkeepers formed the middle class, while the lower class included slaves and farmers. The majority of the workforce, approximately 60% of their income, was dedicated to agricultural tasks, with farmers obliged to pay taxes based on their production. Slaves were compelled to work on construction projects and was overseen by the elite.

column3: The plot of the story seems to have an impact on tragedy. He says in the first paragraph " we must proceed to consider what the poet should aim at, and what he should avoid, in constructing his plots." He then goes on to say that by what method will the specific affect of tragedy be proudced  throughout the plot. The character is another form of ideal tragedy. The character that is not successful, or  "good and just" will also be the charcter who isn't a bad person but is judged because of some "error" or past situation that is now defined as his reputation. Instances like that in movies are predictable which doesn't make them tragedies anymore. The last ideal tragedy is spectacle. The spectacle part of tragedy refers to how things are seen. Such as characters, the set up of the movie or play, how they dress and sound and other things along that line. Spectacle can occur in tragedy because everything isn't as it seems. The way the characters dress act and sound could cover up their true identies. With that being said the people wouldn't expect the nice sweet guy to be the mass murderer of the play. Appearances and how different situations are viewed by the audience plays an important role in tragedy.
column4: "The story's plot plays a crucial role in the genesis of tragedy. The poet must prioritize the poet's goals and what to omit in order to craft a tragedy that transcends the human nature of tragedy. Tragedy can only be achieved through specific methods and each element must resonate with the audience to create a powerful emotional impact. The character that fails or "good and just" will eventually be one of the tragic figures, regardless of their good deeds. Predictable plot devices have little impact on the tragedy's impact, as the audience can anticipate the ending. The spectacle of tragedy focuses on how things are perceived by the audience. Spectacle can enhance tragedy as it allows the audience to perceive the characters and setting in ways that reveal their true nature. This is why a seemingly innocent character might become the murderer in a tragic play. Appearances and how individuals are depicted by the director impact the audience's understanding of the tragedy and the characters’ actions."

column3: First, an ideal tragedy must have a complex plot. Aristotle says, "It should, moreover, imitate actions which excite pity and fear...".  Second, it must have a  tragic hero. This is the main character with a tragic flaw that leads to their demise. Finally, an ideal tragedy must have a turning point  for the main character that goes from good to bad.
column4: A tragic play should have a well-developed plot with multiple conflicts and challenges. It should also feature a tragic hero, a key character with a tragic flaw, and a pivotal turning point that leads the hero down a tragic path.

Aristotle drives the point of ideal tragedys needing to create the feeling of pity into the audience in order for it to be a true tragedy.
